editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A TRVE CHRISTIANS DAILY DELIGHT: BEING The Summe of euery Chapter of the Old and New Teſtaments, ſet downe Alphabetically, in Engliſh Verſe, that the Scriptures we reade may more happily be remembred, and the things forgotten more eaſily recalled.
By Simon Waſtel, ſometimes of Queenes Colledge in Oxford, now Schoole-Maſter of the Free-Schoole in Northampton.

lg.l: A good Diuine hee's counted ſtill,
In Scripture text that hath good skill.

l.hi: Si Chriſtum neſcis, nihil eſt ſi caetera diſcis:
Si Chriſtum bene ſcis, ſatis eſt ſi caetera neſcis.

lg.l: If that thou know'ſt not Chriſt thy King,
No good will humane knowledge bring
If him thou rightly doſt adore,
It is enough, thou needſt no more.

div.q: Bleſſed is he that delighteth, and meditateth in the Law of God day and night. PSAL. 1.2.
div.p: LONDON, Printed by G. Eld and M. Fleſher, for Robert Mylbourne, and are to be ſold at his ſhop at the great South doore of Paules. 1623.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT Honourable, his ſingular good Lord, Sir Robert Spencer Knight, Baron Spencer of Wormeleighton: S. W. Wiſheth all happineſſe temporall and eternall.
div.p:
THE manifold fauours receiued from your Lordſhip, euer ſince my firſt placing in the Free-Schoole of Northampton, as alſo your Honours late promiſed aſſiſtance to helpe the ſaid Schoole to that right whereof it hath been theſe many yeeres vnconſcionably defrauded, hath cauſed me
many times to wiſh that ſome good occaſion might be offered vnto me, whereby I might witneſſe not onely vnto your Honour, but alſo to poſterity, how much I confeſſe my ſelfe obliged vnto you for the ſame. And therefore hauing taken ſome paines to turne the contents of the Bible briefly into Engliſh meeter, for the helpe of weake memories (being incouraged thereunto by the perſwaſions of diuers of my godly learned friends, when they ſaw ſome entrance made thereinto.) Your Honor being in the very Frontiſpice of my deareſt and worthily moſt honoured friends, I determined to dedicate the ſame, together with my humble and beſt ſeruice, vnto your Honor; beſeeching you, that both my ſelfe and it, as alſo our poore wrōged Schoole may ſtill bee patronized and ſhrowded vnder the ſhadow of your Honourable protection: ſo will I not feare what my backe friends can ſay
to my Booke, nor what they can deuiſe or doe againſt my ſelfe; ſo alſo ſhall your Honor (in reſpect of the Schoole) haue the praiſe of the Prophet, to be called, A builder of that waſt place, and a raiſer vp of the foundation thereof; a repairer of that breach, and a reſtorer of thoſe paths to dwell in: And ſo be honoured and eſteemed of me, and all my Succeſſors, as the ſecond Founder thereof, and be paralleld and equalized with Thomas Chipſey, who was the firſt: For,
Non minor eſt virtus quam quaerere parta tueri.
Tis no leſſe pious, things loſt to regaine,
Then for firſt Founders to giue to maintaine.

Vouchſafe I beſeech you (my moſt honoured Lord) as cheerefully to accept of this my poore preſent and widowes mite (being a pawne and pledge of my euer dutifull & thankfull minde) as Artaxerxes is ſaid to haue receiued an handfull of water from the poore Countryman, whoſe
ability would afford no better a gift. So will I euer powre forth my prayers vnto the Almighty Preſeruer of mankinde, the giuer of euery good gift, that hee would bee pleaſed to vouchſafe vnto your Honor, and to all your Honourable Progeny, health of body, length of dayes, with increaſe of grace and honor in this life, and the fruition of eternall bleſſedneſſe in the World to come.

closer.signed: Your Honours euer to command, SIMON WASTELL.

div.head: The Preface to the READER.
div.p:
NOT long agoe (Chriſtian Reader) there was publiſhed a little Book in Latin verſe, called Bibliorum Summula, ſet forth by Maſter Iohn Shaw (a man whom both for his learning and grauity, as alſo for our old and ancient acquaintance (being Schoole-fellowes in Weſtmerland 50 yeeres agoe, and both of Queenes Colledge in Oxford) I did, and doe much eſteeme and respect.) This Booke I perceiued to bee much applauded of the godly learned Miniſters, and of many other Schollers that had ſeene and read the ſame. And therefore after hee had ſent me one, (as a token of his loue) I began to ſtudy how I might teach it to ſpeake Engliſh, being as deſirous to benefit the vnlearned,
as he was the learned; and hauing tranſlated the Bookes of Moſes, and offered them to his and to other learned and graue Miniſters view and cenſures, they did by their perſwaſions ſo pricke & ſpurre me forward, that I could not giue ouer, vntill (through Gods aſſiſtance) I had gone through both the old and new Teſtaments. I confeſſe I haue not preciſely tyed my ſelfe to his method & manner, becauſe the Engliſh tongue is farre more copious then the Latine; but haue taken liberty (according as the contents of each Chapter were longer or briefer) to conclude them ſometimes in two, ſometimes in foure, ſometimes in more Diſticks, with as much breuity (obſeruing perspicuity) as I could. I haue purpoſely laboured to ſpeake plainly, to the capacity and vnderſtanding of the ſimple and ignorant, rather then by poeticall ſtraines to pleaſe the eare, and the eye of the curious learned Readers. Thou haſt alſo not onely the contents of euery Chapter ſet downe in order Alphabetically, with figures to direct thee vnto them, but alſo figures in euery line to direct thee to the verſe
where thou ſhalt find that preſently which thou deſireſt to know, without reading ouer the whole Chapter. Thou haſt alſo a Chronologicall obſeruation of times from Adam to Chriſt, and from Chriſt to Antichriſt. Thou haſt alſo the names of all the Bookes of the Bible, as they follow in order.

Laſtly, thou haſt comforts and encouragements againſt the feare of death, called, the old mans A. B. C. If it ſhall pleaſe thee (gentle Reader) when thou haſt read or heard a Chapter, to read ouer the Contents in meeter once, or twice, thou maieſt be able to rehearſe and ſay the ſaid Contents by heart, and ſo in ſhort time bee acquainted with the Hiſtory of the whole Bible. If any be ſo zealouſly affected with the knowledge of the Scriptures, as the Lord Cromwell was, who (as Maſter Fox recordeth in the Booke of Martyrs, of the fift Edition, page 1075.) got by heart all the new Teſtament of Eraſmus his tranſlation in his iourney to Rome, hee might in ſhorter time get by heart theſe briefe contents of the whole Bible. If therefore the Law of God be
thy delight, (as it was Dauids) this little Book will be a comfortable companion, whether thou walkeſt abroad, or ſtayeſt at home. And finally, if thou reapeſt any increaſe of ſauing knowledge, iuſtifying faith, or holineſſe of life, by theſe my poore labours, to the edification and ſaluation of thy ſoule, I haue all that I deſire, ſauing that I would entreat thee to aſcribe the praiſe and glory of all to God, and to afford mee thy charitable cenſure, well-wiſhings, and prayers.

closer.signed: Thine in any Chriſtian ſeruice that he can performe, S. W.

lg.l: TO keepe vs blameleſſe what excuſe haue we,
If ignorant in Gods Commands we be?
Since, to informe vs, what his pleaſure is,
So many helps we haue that others miſſe:
And are not now compelled to goe ſeeke,
The hard phraz'd Hebrew, nor the copious Greek.
For, God ſpeakes Engliſh to vs; and aſſayes
To worke true knowledge in vs diuers wayes.
Some men interpret, ſome againe expound;
And this our Author here, a meanes hath found
To help the Memorie: And not in vaine,
If others adde endeauor to his paine.
Peruſe it Reader. And ſo mindfull be
Of that, whereof this booke remembers thee;
That others in thy life, may copyed finde,
What thou art hereby taught to beare in minde.

div.head:
To the as truly religious, as learned and worthily beloued Author, and Tranſlator, Mr.
Iohn Shawe, Anag. Oh Shew ani.
& Simone Waſtell. Anag. So well is meant.

lg.l: OH Shew mee many, ani man almoſt,
In this ſo ſinfull, ſin-foule Generation,
That ſtands for true Religions propagation:
Oh, too too few can hereof truely boaſt.
Oh, yet of many, ani for to Shew,
Heauen hath not left vs hopeleſſe: Two are here
By whoſe religious labours may appeare
A happy Hope in Faith and Grace to grow.
Waſtell, So well is meant, ſo well is penn'd
This worthy Worke of thine, this Light, Delight,
That none but Rabſheca with Romiſh ſpight
Can chooſe but Thee & thy ſweet Pains cōmend.
So well is meant (I ſay) this holy labour,
And ſo well form'd, perform'd for pious vſe,
As iuſtly merits each good Chriſtians fauour,
As no ſmall help to th' Booke of Bookes peruſe,
With Scriptures ſacred ſent their Soules to ſauour.
And as tis So well meant, let good men take it,
With like good mind, & their Cōpanion make it.

closer.signed: Your moſt louing (though vnknowne) Friend in Chriſt Ieſus, IOHN VICARS.

div.head: Ad virum vere religioſum D. Simonem Waſtellum: Inue ejus Epitomen, Divini verbi Acroſtichis numeris incluſam.
div.l: SIcui vel laſ • iva placet, vel fabula mendan,
A • nio Latices, aut Helicona petat.
Sanctior Hic vates, Fons purior Iſle ſalutis,
Incubat his ſacris Spiritus almus aquis.
Hîc iterum Moſes Victor pia Carmina ſundit:
Atque iterum Deborae cantica laeta ſtrepunt.
Hîc iterum tentat Caharam Ieſsëia proles,
Et iuv • t ad numeros fila movere tuos.
Hîc iterum Solomon celebrat ſanctos Hymenaeos,
Sponſus vbi ſpargit Lilia, Sponſa Roſas.
Hîc iterum reddunt ſor • es (pia turba) Prophetae,
Verſibus & ſpirant myſtica verba ſuis.
Hîc iterum Chriſti mores & geſta canuntur,
Quicquid agris, pelaco, quicquid & urbe facit.
Hîc iterum [verbo] ſeniorum Muſa ter octo,
Gaudet inauratas increpuiſſe lyras
O quantum rapiunt animos, quaſi numine, quando
Advolitant dulci coelica dicti ſono?
Hûc properent igitur iuvenes, queî Chriſtus amori
Dogmata, q • eîs Domini rellig oſa placent.
Sic Leo mella dabit, Leo Iudae mellea verba:
Sic dabit aeternae Petra ſolutis aquas.

closer.signed: Tuae ſalutis multum ſtudioſus, quondam diſcipulus, ſemper amicus, Iaſper Fiſher.

Their faſting is reprou'd as verse 4 naught:
ſinne verse 8 into thraldome caſts.
HOly verse 3 Sion Gods mount reſtor'd;
they're bid verse 9 be bold to build:
Hee, dwelling there, requires verse 16 good works;
and will verse 18 great comforts yeeld.
IEhovah will reſtore his verse 8 church:
Chriſt comes (a King verse 9 of peace)
Reioyce ô Sion, hee verse 10 defends,
and giues thee verse 12 all encreaſe.
KEepe thee verse 1 from Idolls: ſeeke verse 2 to God:
as they for verse 5 ſinnes were ſlaine,
So will hee verse 6 ſaue his owne verse 10 deare flocke,
and them verse 12 reſtore againe.

LEbanon
verse 1 burnt, the verse 4 elect verse 7 preſeru'd:
the Lord reiects verse 9 the worſt:
The ſtaues of beaut' and verse 10 bands are broke:
the verse 17 Idoll-ſhepherd curſt.

MArke Salems
verse 2 cup of trembling here;
to foes a verse 3 weighty ſtone:
Victorious verse 6 Iudah is reſtor'd:
they mourne verse 9 apart verse 14 each one.
NOw is a fountaine opened wide,
mourners verse 1 to purifie:
Chriſts death verse 7 foretold; two parts verse 8 cut off:
the third part verse 9 God will try.
O Salems ſpoylers, yee verse 1 are ſpoil'd:
Chriſts gracious verse 4 comming ſee:
The remnant ſhall returne to verse 16 God:
their ſpoyles verse 20 ſhall holy be.

div.head: MALACHI.

lg.l:
A Great complaint Malachi
verse 2 makes,
that Iſr'el was vnkind,
Prophane verse 7, and irreligious:
they offred lame verse 23 and blind.
BItter curſes on Prieſts verse 2 pronounc'd;
the Law they verse 8 did neglect:
For verse 17 vnbeliefe, verse 14 adultery,
the Lord did them verse 17 reiect.
CHriſts verse 1 meſſenger verse 2 and verse 4 maieſty:
Prieſts verse 8 rob, and men rebell:
Are verse 13 Infidels: beleeuers verse 16 bleſt,
in vertue that excell.
DEadly plagues are for verse 1 wicked men:
the godly verse 2 all are bleſt:
He bids them ſtudy verse 4 Moſes law:

Eliahs
verse 5 charge expreſt.

div.trailer: The end of the old Teſtament.

lg.l: A Pedigree of verse 1 IESVS CHRIST,
by th'holy Ghoſt verse 12 conceiu'd:
Of Virgin verse 18 borne, who (though with child)
of verse 24 Ioſeph is receiu'd.
BY Star verse 2 the Wiſemen guided are
to Chriſt, whom they verse 11 adore:

They offer gifts: King Herod
verse 16 frets;
and Ioſeph flies verse 14 therefore.
CHildren by verse 16 Herod murthered are:
and then obſerue his verse 21 death:
Ioſeph is ſore verse 22 afraid, yet comes
with Chriſt to verse 23 Nazareth.
DOwn comes verse 16 the holy Ghoſt on Chriſt,
whom God verse 17 from heauen doth grace:

Iohn
verse 3 cries, verse 7 reproues, verse 13 baptizeth Chriſt:
himſelfe he verse 14 doth debaſe.
ENuious verse 4 tempter verse 7 thrice verse 10 repel'd:
to Chriſt the verse 11 Angells come:
Hee verse 17 preacheth: calls verse 18 Apoſtles foure:
and heales verse 23 both all and ſome.
FOr bleſſed verse 3 men Chriſt theſe verse 4 eſteemes:
the City verse 14 ſet on hill:
The verse 15 Candle; verse 13 Salt; light of the verse 14 world:
Chriſt did verse 17 the law fulfill.
GIue eare and learne what verse 21 murther is:
adultery verse 17: what verse 33 to ſweare:
Beare iniuries verse 38; loue verse 44 enemies:
be like thy father verse 48 deare.
HEre Chriſt of verse 5 prayer; of verse 16 faſting, verse 1 almes;
and verse 14 forgiueneſſe doth ſpeake:
firſt verse 25 heauen, then verse 33 earth ſhould ſeeke.
IVdge verse 1 not; nor caſt verse 6 pure things to dogs.
pray: ſtriue verse 13 at any hand
To enter: heare, and doe verse 21 the word:
build not verse 26 vpon the ſand.
KNow the verse 5 Centurions ſeruant's heal'd:
the Leper verse 2 clens'd and tride:
Peters wiues mother's verse 14 alſo cur'd;
and many ſicke verse 16 beſide.
LEarne how Chriſt verse 18 muſt be verse 19 followed.
the ſea made verse 23 calme and fine:
Two men of Diuells verse 28 diſpoſſeſt:
they goe verse 31 into the ſwine.

MAtthew
verse 9 is from the Cuſtome call'd:
the palſie verse 2 man amended:
Diſciples for not verse 14 faſting are
by Chriſt himſelfe defended.
NOw's Iairus daughter verse 23 rais'd from death:
with Sinners verse 10 he doth eate:
Dumb verse 30 Fiend caſt out: the verse 20 blind haue ſight:
hee hath verse 36 compaſſion great.
OVt are the verse 1 twelue Apoſtles ſent:
with wonder-working verse 5 might:
Are verse 5 charged what to doe, and verse 6 ſhunne:
haue precepts iuſt and right.
PErſwading to perſiſt in verse 16 truth,
hee ſaith he will deny
All, that for fear of man verse 33 ſhall flinch,
and from his Goſpell flie.
QVickly John Baptiſt ſends to verse 1 Chriſt:
a Prophet, yea, and verse 9 more,
Hee calls him; and three Cities doth
vpbraid and check verse 2 full ſore.
REvealing to the poore theſe things,
Chriſt yeelds his verse 25 Father praiſe:
And calls to him all burd'ned verse 27 ſoules,
that mourne for ſinfull waies.
SAbbath-breakers verse 2 th'Apoſtles deem'd;
Chriſt doth verse 3 their foes confute,
By verse 3 Scripture, verse 9 reaſon, verse 10 miracle:
reſtores verse 22 the blinde and mute.
THE ſinne vnpardonable verse 31 marke;
th'account of idle verse 36 words:
The ſeekers of a ſigne verse 38 are chek't;
his kindred verse 49 Chriſt records.
VIew here the Parable of verse 3 ſeed;
Chriſt doth the verse 18 ſame expound:
Of verse 33 leauen, verse 24 tares, of verse 31 muſtard-ſeed;
of treaſure verse 44 hid i'th ground.
A Parable o'th verse 45 Pearle, and Net,
that gath'red verse 47 good and bad,
And how Chriſt verse 53 of his Country-men,
no grace nor verse 57 honour had.

BEheaded verse 3 good Iohn Baptiſt
verse 12 is:
of Chriſt what verse 2 Herod thought:
In Deſert he fiue thouſand verse 20 ſeeds,
with loaues verse 17 and fiſh then brought.
CHriſt walkes to his vpon the verse 22 Sea,
and in Geneſar verse 34 land
He heales the ſicke by verse 36 garments hemme,
which was but toucht with hand.
DEſpis'd are Gods verse 3 Commandements,
by mens traditions vaine:
Foure thouſand men and verse 32 moe he feeds verse 17 food:
with loaues and fiſh again.
EVil verse 11 thoughts defile, and not mans
he heales the womans daughter,
And verse 30 multitudes of ſicke and lame,
which then did follow after.
FOr ſigne the Sadduces do verse 1 call;
their leau'n Chriſt verse 6 bids beware:
Th'opinion verse 13 people had of Chriſt:

Peters
verse 16 confeſſion rare.
GOe to verse 21 Ieruſalem Chriſt will;
there death muſt ſuffer ſure:

Peter
verse 22 diſſwades; is Satan verse 23 call'd:
his muſt their croſs verse 24 endure.
Here Ieſus is verse 1 transfigured:
the lunaticke verse 14 made well:
He payeth verse 24 tribute, and himſelfe
his owne verse 22 death doth foretell.
INfant-like verse 1 be yee harmeleſſe, verse 2 meeke,
offend not one verse 7 another:
Learne in all ſcandalls how to verse 15 deale
with euery Chriſtian brother.
KIng calls his ſeruants verse 23 to account:
by this thou well maiſt know
How oft to pardon; how hee's verse 32 plagu'd,
that will no mercy ſhow.
LOe he reſtoreth verse 2 multitudes;
to'th Phariſes verse 3 replies:
Shewes verse 10 who and verse 11 when men marry may:
he babes doth verse 15 bleſſe likewiſe.
MArke verse 16 young man, rich, how verse 23 hardly verse 24 ſau'd;
how ſuch may verse 20 perfect bee:
Who ought forſakes (to follow verse 27 Chriſt)
eternall bliſſe ſhall ſee.
NOw are the Lab'rers call'd, and verse 2 ſet
in Vineyard to take paine:
God is a debtor verse 13 vnto none;
Chriſts death verse 17 foretold againe.
OF Mothers ſuite for her verse 20 two Sonnes;
whom Chriſt doth verse 22 anſwer right;
And thereby verse 26 teacheth lowlineſs:
hee giues two verse 30 blind their ſight.
PVtting their cloaths verse 7 vpon the Colt,
to Salem verse 10 ſo rides hee:
Out of the Temple verse 12 Chapmen whips:
doth curſe the verse 17 fruitleſſe tree.
QVite put to ſilennce verse 23 are the Prieſts:
and ſharpe verse 28 reproofes are ſpent
Vpon them all, becauſe they verse 35 flew
his ſeruants which he ſent.
REgard the Kings ſonnes verse 1 mariage:
let Caeſar haue verse 15 his owne:
Who wanted wedding garment verse 12 is
int' vtter darkeneſſe throwne.
SAdduces here verse 23 confuted are:
the Gentiles verse 9 call'd to'th feaſt:
The Lawyer verse 34 anſwer'd: ſome are pos'd,
about verse 41 our Sauiour Chriſt.
THeir doctrine verse 1 follow, not their liues:
beware of their verse 5 ambition:
Eight woes againſt verse 13 hypocriſie:
Hieruſalems verse 38 perdition.
VNto's Diſciples Chriſt foretells
the Temples verse 2 ouerthrow:
What troubles verse 3 ſhall befall before,
he doth moſt plainly ſhow:
ANd ſignes verse 29 before he comes to iudge:
(the day and time verse 36 not ſure)
As faithfull ſeruants wee muſt verse 42 watch.
his comming euery hower.
BRidegrome is verse 1 met; ten Virgins marke:
hee Talents verse 14 doth verse 19 require:
The verse 31 iudgment day: the ſheepe verse 34 are bleſt:
the verse 41 Goats verse 46 caſt in hell fire.

CHiefe Prieſts verse 3 conſpire: Mary
verse 7 anoints:
the Supper Chriſt verse 36 ordaines:

Sits verse 20 downe with twelue: by Iudas
verse 14 ſold,
thrice praies verse 36 with grieuous paines.
DEni'de is hee verse 69 by Peter thrice:
and is verse 47 betraid by kiſſe:
An eare verse 51 cut off: accus'd verse 61 and ſcoff'd verse 68:
to Ca'phas carried verse 57 is.

ELders verse 1 conſpire: to Pilate
verse 2 bring:
his wife verse 19 puts him in minde:
Hee waſh't his verse 24 hands: verse 3 Iudas is hang'd:
Chriſt doth no verse 23 ſauour find.
FAlſe murth'rer choos'd; Ieſus verse 76 refus'd,
is crown'd verse 29, & nayl'd to'th verse 34 croſſe:
graue ſeal'd; they verse 66 watch his coarſe.
GReat verse 2 earth-quake ſeen: an verse 5 Angell ſhewe
Chriſt verse 6 riſen from the graue.
To Mary Chriſt verse 9 himſelfe appeares:
large bribes verse 12 the ſouldiers haue.
HEre Chriſt verse 16 appeareth to'th eleuen,
who them t'all verse 19 nations ſends:
Hee bids them teach verse 20 all his commands:
his preſence them defends.

ATtend Iohns
verse 1 Office; Chriſt verse 9 baptiz'd,
is tempted verse 12 forty dayes:
He verse 14 preacheth: calls verse 16 Apoſtles foure:
him th'vncleane fiend verse 23 obeyes.
BY him are verse 32 many perſons cur'd;

and Peters
verse 29 moth'r in law:
A Leper likewiſe verse 42 cleanſed is:
the Prieſt him verse 44 cleanſed ſaw.

CHriſt Matthew
verse 14 calls: & heales verse 11 the ſick,
who verse 3 was by foure men borne:
He eates verse 15 with ſinners; His defends
for plucking verse 13 eares of Corne.
DOwn verse 11 fal the Fiends, whom he verse 12 rebuk'd:
he heales the verse 1 withered verse 5 hand:
And verse 10 many moe: then chooſeth verse 13 twelue
to preach in euery Land.
ETernall plagues for verse 29 them that ſaid
one Fiend caſts out verse 22 another:
Who doe his will, by him are verse 35 call'd,
his mother and his brother.
FOwles eate verse 4 ſome ſeed: the verse 14 meaning's told:
communicate verse 21 thy skill:
Some ſeed verse 26 growes well: the verse 30 muſtard ſeed:
ſeas tempeſt Chriſt verse 39 doth ſtill.
GReat Legions of verse 1 Deuills verse 8 caſt out:
of Swine a deuiliſh verse 13 ſlaughter:
Hee heales the womans bloody flux:

and raiſeth Iairus
verse 35 daughter.
HAted is Chriſt verse 3 euen of his owne:
hee verse 34 feedes with verse 38 loaues & fiſh:
Hee giues them power verse 7 ouer Deuills:
Iohns head verse 28 brought in a diſh.
IVdgments verse 14 are diuers of our Chriſt:
th'Apoſtles verse 30 come againe.
Chriſt verse 45 walkes on ſea: who touch his verse 53 hem
are heal'd verse 56 of all their paine.
KEpt are mens precepts verse 8 more then Gods
they verse 3 waſh before they eate:
A Deuill's verse 26 c • ſt out: deaſe verse 35 heare;
no man's verse 15 defil'd with meate.
LEauen verse 14 beware; with verse 1 loaues he feeds
a ſigne they doe verse 17 require:
They ſay verse 27 he's Chriſt: exhorts verse 34 to'th croſſe,
giues blind man verse 27 his deſire.
MArke, Ieſus is verse 2 transfigured:
Elias comne and verse 11 ſlaine:
His death he doth foretell; caſts out
a deafe verse 14 dumb Deuill verse 30 againe.
NOw he verse 33 exhorts to verse 35 lowlineſſe:
they muſt not forbid verse 38 thoſe
That giue verse 39 no ſcandall verse 42 to the iuſt,
nor Chriſtian verse 45 truth oppoſe.
OF verse 2 diuorcement: the babes are verse 13 bleſt:
the verse 23 rich are ſau'd full hard,
But not with verse 27 God: who loſeth verse 29 ought
for Chriſt, verse 30 ſhall haue reward.
PRoud ſuters ſeeke verse 37 preheminence,
and are verse 38 reprou'd therefore:
They're taught to verse 43 beare: his death's verse 45 foretold:
the blind he doth verse 40 reſtore:
QVite dead is verse 20 curſed fruitleſſe tree:
on Aſſe doth Ieſus verse 7 ride:
Doth verse 15 purge the Temple, bids all his
in verse 22 ſtedfaſt ſaith abide.
REeceiue ye ſhall, if ye verse 24 beleeue,
forgiue verse 25 your foes: then pray:
By Iohns witneſſe, (not ſent verse 27 from men)
they know verse 33 not what to ſay.
STout Iewes caſt off; the Gentiles call'd;
this verse 1 parable doth ſhow:
Concerning verse 33 tribute, Chriſt doth here:
Herodian verse 13 ſnares o'rethrow.
THe Sadduces verse 18 conuinced are:
the Scribes verse 35 confuted quite:
He bids beware verse 38 hypocriſie:
praiſeth the widowes verse 41 mite.
VNknown to all when Chriſt ſhal verse 32 come;
he bids vs verse 33 watch and pray:
That verse 35 vnprouided none be found
as his verse 36 owne dying day.
A Stone ſhall not be verse 2 vnthrowne down:
the Goſpell verse 10 preach'd to all:
Profeſſors beaten verse 9: Iewes verse 14 are plagu'd:
how Chriſt our verse 24 Iudge ſhall call.
BY craft they ſeeke verse 1 our Sauiours death:
who is verse 10 for money ſold:

Mary
verse 3 anoints: this treaſon is
by verse 12 Chriſt to his foretold:
CHriſt verse 22 keepes his Supper, ſhewes verse 26 their flight:
is with a verse 43 kiſſe betraid:
Accus'd, verse 53 condemn'd, and ſore verse 65 abus'd:

by Peter
verse 66 thrice denaid.
DEliuer'd to be crucifi'd:

Barrabbas
verse 15 is ſet free:
He faints in bearing verse 21 of his Croſſe:
mock'd verse 20, crown'd with verse 17 thornes is he.
EVen hang'd with verse 27 thieues: reproacht of verse 29 Iewes:
Centurion doth verse 39 confeſſe:
Ioſeph doth beg and verse 43 bury him,
and ſo his loue expreſſe.
FRighted full ſore verse 5, the Angells doe
declare verse 6 to women three,
That Chriſt is riſen from verse 6 the dead;
the place he bids them ſee.
GOing to Emmaus Chriſt verse 12 appears
to two: to verse 9 Magdalen:
Then to'th verse 14 Apoſtles ſent to verse 15 preach:
and ſo aſcends verse 19 to heauen.
A Preface of Lukes Goſpell verse 1 here;

of verse 26 Chriſts, & verse 5 Iohns
verse 24 conception:

Maries, Eliza's
verse 59 propheſie:
Iohns birth and verse 57 circumciſion.
BLeſt bee the God verse 68 of Iſrael
(thus Zachary doth ſing)
Both of verse 76 Iohn Baptiſt, and of Chriſt,
who doth ſaluation verse 71 bring.
CHriſt here is verse 6 borne; the world is verse 1 taxt:
Chriſts verse 8 birth to ſhepheards known
By Angells: for this bleſſing great,
great verse 13 praiſe abroad is blowne.
DAyes eight once verse 21 paſt hee's circumcis'd:
his mother verse 22 purifi'de:

Of Simeon
verse 28, and of Anna old,
Chriſt verse 38 here is propheſide.
EXceedingly hee growes verse 40 in grace:
at Salem ſtayes verse 43 behinde:
Diſputes verse 46, admir'd verse 48: with parents goes:
is verse 51 dutifull and kinde.
FRuits of verse 8 repentance called for:
in verse 20 priſon ſhut is he:
Here Chriſt verse 21 baptiz'd, is grac'd from heauen:
his verse 23 age and pedigree.
GRacious words verse 16 admired are:
tempted verse 2 doth verse 13 ouercome:
Beginnes to verse 14 preach: caſts out a verse 33 Deuill:
and healeth verse 40 all and ſome.
HEE preacheth verse 3 out of Peters ſhip;
hee'l make them verse 10 fiſh for men:
A leper verse 14 clens'd: in deſert verse 16 praies:
the palſie verse 18 cured then.
IN verse 29 Leuies houſe with ſinners eates:
afflictions are verse 34 foretold:
To bottles are the weake compar'd:
and vnto verse 36 garments old.
KNow Phariſes confuted all:
about verse 2 the Sabbath breach:
By verse 3 Scripture, verse 5 reaſon, verse 6 miracle:
hee chooſeth verse 13 twelue to teach.
LEarn who are verse 23 bleſt verse 24 & verse 19 curſt of Chriſt
diſeaſes healed all:
Loue yee verse 27 your foes: heare verse 46 and obey,
leſt like an houſe verse 49 yee fall.
MOre faith in the verse 9 Centurion found;
his abſent ſeruant verse 10 heal'd:
From death is rais'd the verse 11 widowes ſonne:
his thought of verse 24 Iohn reueal'd.

NOw anſwer'd are Iohns
verse 15 meſſengers:
the Iewes no meanes verse 30 can win:
A friend he verse 47 is to ſinners all,
that will verse 50 forſake their ſin.
OF women verse 3 miniſtring to Chriſt:
the verse 4 Parable of Seed,
And of the verse 16 Candle: Chriſt declares
who are his verse 21 friends indeed.
PVffing verse 24 and ſtormy winds rebuk'd:
the woman ſicke verse 43 made ſound:
The dead verse 49 reuiu'd: the verse 37 Gadarenes:
the ſwine by verse 26 deuils drown'd.
QVickly ſends Chriſt verse 1 th'Apoſtles forth:
him Herod faine verse 7 would ſee:
Fiue verse 14 thouſand fed: asks what men verse 18 thinke,
his verse 22 death foretelleth verse 14 he.
REbuk'd are they that ſought verse 55 reuenge:
men muſt verse 23 themſelues deny:
He heales verse 37 a man of Lunacy:
commends verse 46 humility.
SEe patterne of his verse 23 patience mild:
transfigur'd verse 28 where he praies:
His verse 43 death foretold: ſome follow would:
but verse 57 yet they make delayes,
THe ſeuenty are ſent out to preach:
three Cities verse 13 curſed be:
Wherein to verse 20 ioy: for graces verse 21 giuen
his Father thanketh he.
VNto the Lawyers precepts verse 25 giuen:
whom he ſhould loue in heart:

Martha reprou'd, but Mary
verse 41 prais'd,
ſhe choſe the better part.

AS Iohn
verse 1 taught his, ſo teach thou vs:
all good things God verse 11 will giue:
Dumb fiend verse 14 caſt out: blaſphemers verse 18 check'd:
they bleſt verse 28 that godly liue.
BVt ſigne of verse 29 Ionas, none ſhall be:
he often woe verse 42 doth cry
To verse 52 Lawyers, Scribes verse 44 and Phariſes,
for groſſe verse 47 hypocriſie.
CHriſt bids them verse 1 hate hypocriſie:
of fearing men verse 4 he warnes:
Of verse 15 auarice, by that rich verse 16 man
that builded bigger barnes.
DEſire not verse 22 wealth: Gods verse 31 kingdome ſeek:
watch ſtill in euery verse 36 place:
Giue verse 33 almes: attend verse 36: look for the verse 49 croſſe:
ô take this time verse 54 of grace.
ENter in at the verse 24 narrow gate:
repent verse 3, or you muſt verse 5 periſh:
The tree verse 9 cut downe: the crooked verse 10 heald:
growth where the Lord verse 18 doth cheriſh.
FOwles build verse 19 their neſts: the verse 21 leauen'd meale:
he Herod fox verse 33 doth call:
O Salem thou my verse 34 Prophets ſton'd,
behold thy verse 35 wofull fall.
GOe ſit verse 10 below: the d opſie verse 2 heal'd:
the verse 11 proud God will abaſe:
Feaſt thou verse 12 the poore: all worldly men
in verse 15 heauen can haue no p • ace.
HIs children muſt account before
what verse 26 Chriſtian life will coſt,
Leſt they reuolt, verse 34 and be like ſalt
that hath his verse 35 ſauour loſt.
IN heauen (when verse 10 ſinners turn to God)
exceeding ioyes abound:
This taught by verse 4 ſheepe, verse 8 ſiluer, and verse 11 ſonne,
once loſt but verse 32 after found.
KNow th'vniuſt verse 1 Stewards dealing prais'd:
the Phariſes verse 14 reprou'd:
Rich verse 19 Glutton verse 23 damn'd: the poor mans ſoule
conuei'd verse 22 to heauen and lou'd.
LEpers here verse 11 ten are clens'd by Chriſt:
one muſt verse 3 forgiue another:
The verse 6 power of faith, they're curſt by Chriſt
that ſcandalize their brother.
as in the time verse 26 of Noe
So ſhall it bee; ſome ſhall be verse 34 ſafe,
and ſome ſhall verse 36 taſt of woe.
NOte widowes verse 3 importunity:
two in the verse 9 Temple pray:
A Ruler would haue verse 18 followed Chriſt,
but riches did him verse 23 ſtay.
OF children that were verse 15 brought to Chriſt:
of verse 31 death doth mention make:
The blinde verse 35 reſtor'd, they heauen verse 9 ſhall haue
that ſuffer for verse 30 his ſake.

PIlling Zacheus
verse 1 turn'd by Chriſt:
ten pieces verse 11 giuen to ten:
With verse 28 triumph Chriſt to Salem rides,
and verse 41 weepeth o're it then:
QVite out o'th Temple verse 45 Sellers driu'n:
hee daily taught verse 47 them there:
The Rulers ſought to take his life;
but verse 48 they the people feare.

REhearſe frō whence Iohns
verse 4 baptiſm was:
let Caeſar haue verse 25 his owne:
The Parable o th Vineyard verse 9 marke:

Chriſt, Dauids
verse 41 Sonne is knowne.
SAdduces are convinc'd by Chriſt;
they verse 27 ſay none riſe from graue:
Beware of verse 46 Scribes which make great ſhews;
but great verse 47 damnation haue.
THe widows mite verse 3 commended is:
the ſignes before verse 25 laſt day:
The ruine verse 5 of the Temple told:
he bids them verse 34 watch alway.

VIle verse 2 Iewes conſpire: Iudas
verse 6 betraies:

• oth defend:

• le are not verse 27 worth a pin • e.

for ſo the Deuills verse 19 beleeue:
The rich regard not more verse 3 then poore:
ſuch pitty loue verse 13 releeue.
much good verse 9 or ill it workes:
The godly wiſe are verse 17 peaceable:
in them no verse 18 enuy lurks.
DEtraction and falſe iudgment verse 11 hate:
remember ſtill thine verse 14 end:
All verse 4 whoredomes fly: bee verse 6 humble ſtill:
thy wayes to verse 14 God commend.
EVermore weepe yee verse 1 wicked rich:
bee verse 7 patient; ſing and verse 14 pray:

AL praiſe for grace, loue, hope in Chriſt:
wee with his verse 29 blood were bought:
As borne verse 23 anew, fly former verse 14 luſts:
all glory of man verse 24 is • ought.
yee are elect verse 9 and deare:

to Rulers all with feare,
ſuffer for verse 14 chriſtian lore:

whom An • ells all adore.
DYe vnto ſinne verse 1 as Chriſt is dead:
the end of all's at hand:
Reioyce verse 13 if thou • e wrong'd for Chriſt:
where ſhall the verse 18 ſinners ſtand?
ELders ſhould learne verse 2 to feed their flocks
with care, but not verse 3 as Lords:
Submit yee verse 5 younger: Satan verse 8 ſeekes:

ADde to your faith a godly life;
my death is verse 14 neare at hand:
Chriſt to be verse 16 God, by voyce verse 17, by word,
and ſight we verse 19 vnderſtand.
BLaſphemous verse 1 teachers terrifi'd:
the Angells were verse 4 not ſpar'd:
Iuſt verse 7 Lot preſeru'd: back ſliders all,
to dogs and ſwine verse 22 compar'd,
CHriſt will come verse 14 iudge, though mockers ſcoffe:
the verse 10 heauens muſt paſſe away:
Bee verse 11 godly therefore; grow verse 18 in grace:
expect that verse 12 iudgment day.
A Fellowſhip with God wee haue,
and Chriſt whom we verse 1 haue known:
T'aſſure thee pardon for thy verse 6 ſinne
let holy life be verse 7 ſhown.
BVt wee haue verse 6 nought to doe with him,
if wee in ſinne ſhall liue:
Confeſſing and forſaking verse 9 ſinnes,
hee will them all forgiue.
COmforts verse 1 for ſins of verse 2 weakneſſe learne:
whom verse 9 wee muſt loue: what verse 15 hate:
To know God verse 3 is to keepe his law:
ſhun verse 20 Antichriſts deceit.
DEnying Ieſus to be Chriſt,
is verse 22 Antichriſtian pride:

doe you in verse 21 Chriſt abide.
EVen now wee are the ſonnes of verse 2 God,
and ſhall with him appeare:
Who hope for this, they purge verse 3 themſelues:

FOrſaking verse 9 ſinne (as borne of God)
and louing verse 11 one another,
The world verse 13 will hate: they're murtherers
that hurt verse 15 and hate their brother.
GIue not credit to verse 1 all teachers;
by verse 2 rules of faith them verse 3 try:
God lou'd vs verse 19 firſt; loue verse 20 brotherly:
true loue verse 18 makes feare to flye.
HEre faith doth verse 4 conquer all the world:
who verse 1 loues Iehovah right,
Doth loue his verse 1 children; keepe his verse 3 lawes,
which eaſie are and light.
IN Chriſt verse 12 eternall life is giuen:
three verse 7 witneſſes all one:
Chriſt verse 14 heares vs pray: for ſinnes to death
ſee verse 16 prayers thou make none.
A Lady with her verse 5 children, hee
b • ds in true loue verse 6 perſiſt:
Leſt that they lo • e verse 8 thereby, and bids
ſeducers verse 10 all reſiſt.
AN hearts verse 3 delight it is to mee,
to heare of thy verse 5 good deeds:
Who verse 3 walkſt in tru • h; who ſtrangers, ſaints,
and verse 7 preachers poore doſt feed.
BVt prating proud verse 10 Diotrephes
doth vſe malicious words:
VVhom verse 11 follow not; Demetrius,
each man great praiſe verse 12 affords.

(of old verse 4 ordain'd for hell)

Bruite verse 10 beaſts: like Balaam, Kaine,
verse 15 & Core,
to'th verse 13 Deuill their ſou • es they ſell.
BVt godly men by godly verse 20 meanes,
doe grow in verse 21 gracious ſtate,
Reſcuing others out of verse 22 ſnares:
fleſh ſpotted garments hate.
ASian Churches verse 4 Iohn ſalutes
from God in Trinity:
Chriſt comes to verse 7 iudge: all ſhall him ſee,
his might verse 14 and maieſty.
BEhold what Iohn to'th Angells verse 8 writes,
of Smyrna, Epheſus:
In Thyatira verse 18 what defects:
what's prais'd in verse 12 Pergamus.
COncerning verse 9 Smyrna (rich in grace)
the Lord doth well verse 10 approue.
Th'Epheſian Church is greatly verse 4 blam'd,
for loſing her firſt loue.
DEad Sardis is (though verse 1 ſaid to liue)
euen all except verse 4 a few:
They're bid repent: keepe verse 3 what they heard,
or ſhortly ſure ſhould rue.
EVen in that Citie ſome there verse 4 were
who kept their garments pure:
Who worthy were to walke in verse 5 white:
they ſhall bee ſaued ſure.
FAithfull Philadelphia's verse 10 prais'd:
but Laodecea's told
That God will ſpew her out, becauſe
ſhee's neither verse 16 hot nor cold:
GOds verse 2 throne, foure beaſts, ſeuen lamps he ſees,
the verse 5 Chriſtall verse 6 ſea, and ſounds:
The Elders fall before the throne,
and there they verse 10 caſt their crownes.
HEre opened is the ſealed verse 6 Booke,
by that Lamb which was ſlaine:
The Elders verse 12 praiſe him, he by's blood
them verse 9 ſau'd from endleſſe paine.
IN verse 1 order verse 3 opened are the verse 4 ſeales:
foure horſes: ſoules verse 9 complaine:
Sun verse 12 darke: ſtars verse 13 fall: men call to verse 16 rocks
to free them from their paine.
KNow ſoules verse 9 innumerable ſeal'd:
ſaluation verse 10 here they cry:
In Lambs blood are their white robes waſht:
teares verse 14 wip'd from verse 17 eu'ry eye.
LOe Angels ſound their verse 2 Trumpets ſeuen,
foure verse 6 ſounding, cauſe complaints:
Great verse 7 plagues doe verse 13 follow: Chriſt perſumes
the verse 3 prayers of the Saints.
MArke helliſh ſmoake verse 2 obſcures the Sun:
hence verse 3 Locuſts verse 5 ſting full ſore:
Firſt woe is verse 12 paſt: ſixt Angell verse 13 ſounds,
here loos'd are verse 14 Angels foure.
NOw with the Booke (which verse 9 Iohn muſt eat,
an Angell ſtrong appeares:
In belly bitter, ſweet in verse 9 mouth:
an end of time he verse 6 ſweares.
OF pow'r giu'n to verse 6 two4462. witneſſes:
Beaſt verse 7 kils them, and verse 8 they lye
Vnburied verse 9, and yet riſe verse 12 5322. againe,
Chriſt verse 15 reignes eternally.
PAined in child birth,4162. Dragon verse 2 ſeekes
her child for to deuoure,
She verse 6 flying, is by him verse 15 purſu • :
Chriſt conquers by his verse 10 power.
QVelling Dragon here giues his power
to'th verse 2 monſtrous horned beaſt:
falſe verse 15 worſhips here increaſt.
REad how Chriſt verse 1 on mount Sion ſtands
with verse 4 his redeemed all:
An Angell doth the Goſpell verse 6 preach:
reade here verse 8 of Babels fail.
SOre verse 9 plagues for all beaſt-worſhippers,
who verse 10 take his marke or name,
In head or hand, or print thereof,
euen verse 11 endleſſe fire and flame.
THe harueſt of the verse 15 world is here,
the ſickle eke of God;
The Vintage, wine-preſſe of his verse 20 wrath,
without the City trod.
VNto the verse 2 Lord the victors verse 3 ſing:
the Temple verse 5 op'ned ſee:
The ſeuen verse 1 laſt plagues; ſeuen verse 7 vials here
with Gods wrath filled be.
ALL floods and verse 4 fountaines feele theſe plagues,
the verse 2 earth, the verse 3 ſeas, and verse 8 ſun:
The men that had the marke verse 2 o'th Beaſt,
with grieuous ſores vndone.
BEaſt ſeat is plagu'd they all verse 11 blaſpheme:

All they are bleſt that watchfull are,
and verse 15 keepe their garments pure.
COme ſee the purple ſcarlet Whore,
with verse 4 golden cup in hand:
Drunke with the blood of martyr'd verse 6 Saints,
ſhe ſhed in euery land.
DEſcrib'd is here verse 5 great Babylon:
what by ſeuen verse 9 heads are meant:
What by ten verse 12 hornes: I ambs verse 14 victory:
the great Whores puniſhment.
EVen as a cage of verse 2 vncleane birds,
where ſp'rits and fiends doe dwell,
Great Babylon is now become,
and is falne downe to hell.
FLy out of her ( verse 4 my people deare)
the Kings and verse 9 Merchants all
Lament for her, but all Gods Sa n • s
reioyce verse 27 to ſee her fall.
GOd (for auenging of his verse 1 Saints,
and iudging the great4362. Whore)
Is magnified for his loue,
and verse 2 for his glorious power.
HEre is the verse 7 m • riage of the Lamb:
Iohn fals at verse 11 th'Angels feet,
He him reproues: the fowles verse 17 are call'd
the fleſh of Kings to eate.
INto the pit is verse 3 Satan caſt:
they holy are verse 6 and bleſt,
That in this life riſe from their ſinne,
in heauen with verse 6 Chriſt they reſt.
KNow verse 7 Satan loos'd: Gog and verse 8 Magog:
the Deuill caſt verse 10 into hell:
The great verse 12 Aſſize: the godly verse 13 ſau'd:
they damn'd verse 15 that did not well.
LOe both new heauen & earth verse 1 appeare,
new verse 2 Salem in his ſight,
Moſt glorious, needing neither Sunne
nor Moone verse 23 to giue her light.
MArke eke Chriſts verse 2 Bride: all verse 4 teares remou'd:
the victors verse 7 ſhall haue all:
To Salem, Kings their verse 24 riches bring:
in hell the fearfull verse 8 fall.
NOte here the Riuer verse 2, Tree verse 1 of life,
which ſauing health afford:
The verse 9 Angell will not worſhipt be:
adde nothing to verse 18 this word.

q.l: Ye Saints on earth be of good cheere,
The darts of Death ye need not feare.

lg.l: ACcountſt thou death a dreadful thing,1 Cor. 15.55
Which hath by Chriſt now loſt its ſting?

So followes death, a life that laſts.
COffin this corps and lay't in graue,1 Cor. 15.53

DEbt due to God I hereby pay,2 Tim. 4.6.
By dying at th'appointed day.
EXceeding welcome Death's to mee, Heb. 9.27.
All men muſt die, no man is free.
FVll happy man that dies in faith: Reu. 14.13.
His goodworks follow him, Chriſt ſaith.
GLad are the Saints diſſolu'd to be, Phil. 1.23.
To liue with Chriſt, his face to ſee.
HE well may quake and feare to dye, Reu. 6.16.
That in his filthy ſinnes doth lye.
IN Death is gaine, it's gate of Life:1 Theſ. 4.14
Laſt night; a ſleepe; an end of ſtrife.

Death will I meet: I will not flee.

Death by his de • th, and law fulfill'd.

The thoughts of death will make thee mend.

Admire the greatneſſe of his loue.
2 Cor. 5.6.OF earthly Pilgrims death from God,
Makes vs poſſeſt of Heauens abode.

Why then doth death me t • rrifie?

Why then ſhould death afflict our harts?

Hath ſo dec • eed that all muſt dye.

At laſt ſhall haue a deadly fall.
